**Divine Lots of the Four Sage Perfected Lords**

*Scripture Title:* *Divine Lots of the Four Sage Perfected Lords*
*Author:* Unknown
*Volume:* One
*Source Text:* *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, Orthodox Section, Part One

**Divine Lots of the Four Sage Perfected Lords**
**Celestial Admonitions for the World**

To seek glory through deceit is to gain no renown.
Wealth amassed through exploitation brings calamity upon descendants.
Cultivate virtue with mindfulness, and fortune and blessings shall descend.
Curb desires, diminish self-interest, and your destiny shall endure.

Do not deceive in darkness, nor betray the Three Luminaries.
Be upright and selfless, with a loyal and sincere heart.
Heaven and Earth bestow blessings; the gods stand guard beside you.
Prolong life and transcend hardship—prosperity shall surely come.
If you heed my words, all afflictions shall vanish like the sea.

When praying, first state your native place and name, then declare:
*"For [such-and-such a matter], I humbly invoke the Perfected Lords—*
*Marshal Tianpeng the Great, Vice-Marshal Tianyu,*
*Lord Xusheng the Protector of Virtue, and Lord Zhenwu the Spiritually Responsive—*
*along with the gods of Heaven and Earth, who witness all things.*
*I now cast this lot: may good or ill be revealed,*
*fortune or misfortune be foretold, life or death be decided—*
*let the judgment be without doubt."*

---

**First Lot** □□ *Lower-Lower* **Uphold the Old**

From dawn to dusk, toil without rest,
Seeing only gold, not the man.
Though hoarded wealth may rot,
In time, even blossoms turn to dust.

The soaring dragon transforms when the hour is right—
Today, its ascent is fulfilled.
Plans and wealth-seeking bring great fortune;
Seeking office and promotion leave no doubt.

The fierce general storms the palace gates—
How dare petty schemes stir conflict?
You must pay homage at the golden gate,
Where lords above and below stand in harmony.

**Sacred Intent:**
Chasing profit at dawn, abandoning truth for delusion.
What is amassed cannot be dispersed—retribution follows slander.
Hold fast to the ordinary; do not scheme.
Do not stir litigation; marriages shall prosper.
The sick recover slowly; travel faces obstacles.
Actions fall short—no path lies ahead.
Auspicious in autumn, inauspicious in spring and winter.
Selling goods is favorable.
Litigation brings no trouble; buying and selling yields no profit,
Or if slight gains come, they cost great effort.
For those under fifty, illness lingers but does not last.
The young should recover early; lying abed longer is no harm.
Affected by earth, but smallpox is no threat.
Sudden illness—if young, sweat comes in seven days, and life is secure.
Marriage brings discord; if the husband enters the wife’s home, misfortune follows.
Seeking livestock or servants brings ill fortune.
Studying medicine or crafts is inauspicious; lost items are hard to recover.
Whether early or late, reunion is delayed and difficult.
Borrowed items are mostly not returned, or only a few.

Relocation brings misfortune; only guarding the old homestead is fitting.
Household members are afflicted by earth, with taboos unsettling peace.
Cultivate blessings to protect them—childbirth should be swift; delay makes official promotion difficult, though greatly auspicious.
Sell goods promptly when selling; documents remain unsigned, and delay prevents completion.
Those entrusted prove deceitful.
Buy goods promptly when buying; plans and actions come to fruition.
Obstacles arise; farming yields no harvest.
Meet noble persons at once—delay brings no success.
Acupuncture and moxibustion require choosing an auspicious day.
Cherishing flowers, yet rain falls; loving the moon, dark clouds arise.
At the feast, no matter seems settled, yet quarrels still contend.

[Missing characters] Second: Greatly Auspicious. Action and use bring advancement.
Seek shelter early to secure profit—
Diligently follow ancient methods, never overstepping time.
Reforming what is corrupt is people’s constant wish;
When deeds align with the heart, great rewards are enjoyed.
The tiger leaves the great forest, stirring the crowd—
Though people see it, they remain anxious and doubtful.
Though it harbors no intent to harm,
It still causes false alarms and suspicious affairs.
How can mountain dwellers host clamorous guests?
Better to cultivate the mind and refine oneself.
Amid all things, remain patient;
Burning with effort in alchemy is but vain labor.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Follow rules and norms, establish oneself by the Dao.
From long stillness comes the thought of movement—
Ever diligent and earnest.
Relocation is auspicious; plans proceed as the heart desires.
Marriage brings harmony; the ill recover lightly.
All matters flow smoothly; litigation brings joy.
Adhering to the Sage’s lot,
All desires prosper and flourish.

Divining marriage is auspicious.
Acquiring goods is of little value; selling goods is favorable.
Moving residence is auspicious.
Litigation brings no trouble; household and family are at peace.
Seeking office brings delayed promotion, yet rank is assured.
Illness should be treated swiftly.
Performing blessings is fitting—
For the elderly, recovery is difficult;
For the young, outcomes vary between good and ill.

Medication meets obstruction; pox sores remain unstable.
For distant travel, fewer companions bring good fortune.
The traveler arrives—if not, returns within two months.
Lost items lie within the home; seek them early, for delay brings no sight.
Household members meet good fortune.

After long absence, the traveler appears—within a day or two, news arrives.
Selling goods or matters should be done promptly; delay brings difficulty.
Pregnancy struggles to bear; a daughter is born.
Performing blessings—
The child is born now.
Seeking a physician or entering school is auspicious.
Entrusting matters to two people brings good fortune.
Trade is auspicious.
Documents meet obstruction, yet fortune prevails.
Borrowing from three people is auspicious.
Purchasing livestock, fields, or homes brings swift profit.
Joyful reunion with kindred spirits—withered willows bloom halfway.
Pursuing good fortune ahead, the heart’s desires are fulfilled in later days.

**Third: Moderate Fortune – From Adversity Comes Prosperity**
Exhausting diligence in hope of success,
Only to be met with sorrow and bitter countenance.
Worry not for the vain depletion of treasures—
Why toil in vain without holding to the mean?

From adversity now comes prosperity;
The dragon’s blade, polished, sheds its old dust.
Say not that self-restraint holds no other hope—
Even in seclusion, wealth is gained.

In office, slanderers arise,
Yet promotion follows in time.
Best to stay home, uphold the Dao,
And naturally, heroes appear within the household.

The Sage’s intent declares:
The times run contrary, unable to hold to constancy.
Diligence exhausted, one suffers calamity instead.
Lost items invite misfortune; actions turn ill.
In all matters, plan early and act in secret.
Great losses of wealth—best to maintain the norm.

Divining purchases—fields, homes, livestock, or servants prove difficult.
See goods and buy swiftly; to haggle further brings no profit.
Illness affects young and old.
If untimely, first ill, then good.

Household spirits are restless; marriage harms the husband.
Efforts fail; farming is laborious.
No harvest—hold to the old; selling goods is favorable.
Litigation is troublesome; plans and actions falter.
Old foundations are sound; new ventures are difficult.
Lost livestock or servants are hard to recover.
Childbirth is difficult; mother and child face peril.
Performing blessings may yield a son.
Entrusting matters to others brings no success—only obstruction.
Documents bring no benefit; wealth is lost.
Relocation is inauspicious.
Borrowing brings no trade; commerce is unfavorable.
Holding to the old brings good fortune; change invites danger.
The tripod lacks a leg—cooking must adapt to the times.

**Fourth: Moderate Fortune – Cautious Restraint**
Say not that minor illness is but a fleeting worry—
Time and tide wait for none.
If one plans early within the Dao,
Perhaps peril may yet yield safety.

Laboring heart and strength to succeed,
Only to see the blossoms scattered by a gust of wind.
Yet if the Eastern Lord lends a gentle hand,
Another branch blooms in the distance.

Wind spurs lightning, thunder serves as messenger;
Drought breeds demons in the waters where dragons twist.
If one can avoid neither,
Timing and harmony suffice for excellence.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Be cautious in small matters, hold to oneself, and serve the spirits wholeheartedly.
Fulfill old vows early to avoid calamity.
Litigation is unfavorable; do not divine marriage.
Travel should be halted; the road is fraught with delay.
Wealth is modest; illness may yet be spared.
All aligns with the Dao—first dark, then bright.

Divining illness—vows bring first ill, then good.
Prolonged affliction is no concern, but the elderly face difficulty.
Pox sores require blessings; childbirth demands swift action—first ill, then good.
Trade is modest; meet people promptly—two or three crops should be harvested early, or none at all.
Speak of goods quickly; marriage is inauspicious.
Adopting or moving into a home is ill-fated.
Travel stirs the heart, but the body remains—
The traveler arrives in two or three days.
If not, delay brings good fortune in litigation.
Spending to buy livestock brings swift success; delay brings difficulty.
Seeking office or promotion—rank comes late, and desires are unmet.
Purchasing goods, fields, or homes should be done quickly; delay brings failure.
Lost items appear at once; if delayed by a day, they vanish.
Matters should be settled swiftly; delay brings change.
Household and family face misfortune.
Performing blessings brings peace.
Entrusting matters to others is favorable.
Noble aid comes late and fails.
Trade is difficult; commerce should be swift.
Relocation is ill-fated.
Borrowing should be done promptly, though others may interfere.
Documents appear at once; delay brings failure.
Seeking physicians or studies is difficult with delay.
Dwelling in peace yet fearing danger,
Deep emotions bring separation.
Before good fruit can be sought,
First, one must suffer the loss of a branch.

**Fifth: Moderate Fortune – Beneficial Action**
With good intent, plan and scheme together—
Profit flows endlessly to meet your desires.
Do not forget good deeds in this pursuit,
Lest the withered vessel drift in the waves.

The sailing ship meets favorable winds without doubt;
Crossing the river is timely.
The Great Wall of ten thousand li is within reach—
Plans succeed as hoped, matters proceed as scheduled.

Two merchants seeking profit—
Best to set out and leave their homeland.
In three, five, or seven days, they reach Chang’an,
Where goods are traded—do not linger in the market.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Trade is most favorable; unite in purpose and plan.
For the elderly and ill, peril is like a lone boat.
Marriage is harmonious; plans and hopes may be pursued.
Illness wavers, yet without resolution, there is no worry.
The traveler arrives soon; litigation brings no detention.
Silkworms and fields bring good fortune; the household thrives in ease.

Divining wealth—buying, selling, and acquiring goods is favorable, though partnerships are inauspicious.
Litigation brings no trouble; marriage is auspicious.
Farming yields harvest; travel is fortunate.
The traveler arrives soon or late; seeking office or promotion benefits illness.
Those in their thirties and forties face no harm;
Those above forty should act swiftly and perform blessings.
Pox sores are stable; the elderly may die.
Purchasing fields, homes, livestock, or servants is auspicious.
The household—old in peril, young at peace.
Entrusting matters to others brings swift good fortune.
Relocation is greatly auspicious.
Lost items appear after delay; plans and actions should be swift—
Delay brings no success within two or three days.

Childbirth—on even-numbered days brings peace and good fortune.
Selling goods—profit lies in swift sale; trade and commerce are auspicious.
Written contracts and transactions will not succeed.
For cart-making, the hub must be shaped with skill, relying on a master craftsman’s hand.
Layered mountains form brocade; fallen flowers bloom again.

Hexagram Six: "Great Auspiciousness in Mind" – Beneficial for Action and Use
To seek a foundation in letters and plans,
Why doubt or devise schemes?
Simply maintain a heart upright and just—
Naturally, transactions yield profit and surplus.

Mandarin ducks, parted, fly in two directions;
Schemes and wealth-seeking remain unfulfilled for now.
Better to hold fast to the old—no need for change;
Advance or retreat, hesitation lingers still.

Dwelling in peace is best within the village;
Should you wish to relocate, no cause for concern.
Even in solitude, all remains well;
Profit and loss in wealth cannot be matched.

The Sage’s Intent declares:
In all literary and legal matters, no loss.
In all schemes and plans, all affairs are peaceful and auspicious.
For kinship and harmony, contracts and deeds proceed smoothly.
In litigation, justice prevails; illness does not turn grave.
In action and change of heart, ten thousand things succeed without fail.

Divining wealth—seek modest gains; when meeting others, patience is key.
Wealth is not lacking; purchasing goods is auspicious.
Selling goods is auspicious.
In troubling matters, caution; litigation is favorable.
Farming yields a meager harvest; travel should be swift.
The traveler arrives soon; illness and old age pose no harm.
For the young, improvement comes in two or three days;
Prolonged delay brings difficulty.

The pox subsides peacefully; marriage is auspicious. Harmony enters the household, all is propitious; the home and family remain at peace. Transactions conclude smoothly, though delay may hinder success. Purchasing land, dwellings, or servants is greatly auspicious. Plans and undertakings face initial difficulty, then ease. Childbirth is peaceful; bearing a son brings noble fortune. Seeking office or promotion brings great advantage. Relocation is auspicious; entrusting matters to others follows the pattern of initial difficulty then ease. Documents bear the vigor of *qi*—propitious. When fish transform into dragons, the time of change arrives; cease speaking of ceaseless rains.

Azure clouds reappear in joy; a single thunderclap heralds the rains.

---

**Hexagram Seven: "Auspicious Rain" – Two Auspicious Omens in Motion**
*When talent and spirit ascend to knock upon the heavens,*
*Deep illness vanishes at once—divine merit is shown.*
*Whether young or old, all receive the blessings of this rain;*
*Its application is like tilling soil in a year of abundance.*

Withered trees meet spring and bloom with color;
Suddenly, branches flourish, sprouting new shoots.
Let no one cut them for firewood—
Wait until spring deepens, and they blossom again.

Travel east to Zhejiang for trade;
In Jiangxi, they speak of new tea.
Do not go east for business—
Buying tea there is like embroidering flowers upon brocade.

The Sage’s Intent declares:
Within, one’s essence is concentrated, making resonance easy to attain.
Though beset by worries, what need is there for excessive concern?
The sick gradually recover; chronic ailments also fade.
Fortune comes as heavenly aid, yet follows human cultivation.
Young and old are safe and auspicious; litigation does not detain.
Plans and endeavors hold promise; planting and weaving yield full harvests.

Divining wealth—three or four parts are attainable. Purchasing goods is like *Gouchen* (a celestial sign); selling goods is slow. Litigation is auspicious; relocation is auspicious. Resolving matters is auspicious; entrusting others follows the pattern of delayed success. In trade, lost items are hard to recover. Travel is auspicious; the traveler arrives in one or two days. Illness in the old or young poses no harm—praying to heaven is auspicious. The pox subsides peacefully; buying livestock, land, dwellings, or servants is auspicious. Marriage is auspicious; plans and undertakings succeed. Small-minded people may interfere, but losing wealth is auspicious. The home and family remain at peace; trade prospers.

Childbirth is harmonious; seeking office is auspicious.
Though one has not yet reached the rank of minister,
The blue clouds spread in pursuit.
Spring’s boundless beauty
Shines upon the Jade Pool.

---

**Hexagram Eight: "Adversity and Obstruction" – Clinging to the Old**
A foundation of hardship wearies those who sustain it;
Endless toil in base affairs blinds one to opportunity.
Livestock suffer losses—minor setbacks—
Yet greater worries arise among the household.

Seeing a fishing boat struggle upstream,
It docks here, lingering in hesitation.
Once the first rapids are passed, one might think the worst is over—
But ahead lie even more treacherous shoals.

Matters of the heart are hard to pursue;
If you proceed, fortune will diminish.
This is where wealth is lost on the road,
Where surging waves engulf the bright pearl.

The Sage’s Intent declares:
One possesses ancestral legacy yet fails to preserve it.
Greed knows no bounds; one exhausts schemes in vain.
Livestock perish, bringing sorrow to the household.
Plans come to naught; the sick recover slowly.
Litigation is lost; all actions court peril.
One should cling to the old and not seek change.

Divining wealth—trade yields meager returns. Purchasing goods is steady, but endeavors fail. Litigation has a clear outcome; relocation is auspicious. Selling goods is slow; farming depends on timing. Travel is inauspicious; the traveler arrives in two or three days. If they do not, wealth is lost. The old face misfortune in illness; the young endure prolonged hardship without harm. The pox is slow to heal; trade is unprofitable. First marriages face no obstacles, but remarriage is ill-advised. Seeking heirs is inauspicious; litigation is difficult at first, then eases. Purchasing land, dwellings, servants, or livestock is inauspicious; plans and undertakings are uncertain. Trade is unpropitious. Lost items are hard to recover; the household suffers misfortune. Childbirth is difficult; entrusting matters to others is unlikely to succeed. Seeking office or promotion is slow.

When treasures transform with the times,
Why do matters not return?
Fingers point to the setting sun—
A lone boat refuses to rest.

---

**Hexagram Nine: "Receiving Blessings" – Transcending the Mundane**
Longing to leave the old and embrace the new,
One encounters flourishing fortune, and aspirations expand.
Home and family are at peace, free from other concerns;
Hiding one’s light and biding time, one emerges from the dust.

Orchids in spring’s splendor are fragrant and lovely;
Chrysanthemums in autumn’s bloom are even finer.
Heaven and earth each follow their own inclinations—
Unbound by restraint, they open in succession.

How to address matters of two minds?
One must follow fate with reverence and pass through cautiously.
Yet the time of opportunity is not far off—
Though not grand, it is worthy of praise.

The Sage’s Intent declares:
After adversity comes prosperity; aspirations will unfold.
The long-established home is peaceful; one transcends the mundane.
All actions and plans succeed without fail.
Clinging to the old brings mediocrity; nearly achieved goals may collapse.
Trade proceeds without obstruction; fields and silkworms are fully prepared.
Changes and actions will surely bring satisfaction.

Divining wealth—change brings auspiciousness. Purchasing and selling goods are auspicious; relocation is auspicious. Litigation is auspicious. Most matters see partial success; farming yields two- or threefold. First marriages are auspicious; remarriage is mediocre. Seeking heirs is auspicious. Travel is auspicious; the traveler arrives in two or three days. The old face difficulty in illness; the young endure prolonged hardship, which is also difficult. The pox resolves with blessings; litigation is auspicious. Purchasing land, dwellings, servants, or livestock is auspicious. Plans and undertakings should proceed swiftly. Lost items should be sought immediately; delay makes recovery unlikely.

Seeking official position or promotion—unattainable. Household and family members are at peace; do not speak of borrowing. Childbirth proceeds smoothly; documents bring delayed auspiciousness. Transactions are slow to conclude; entrusting others with matters may fail. Venturing into trade is greatly auspicious.

For months on end, rain falls frequently,
Only at dusk does the sky begin to clear.
Raising one’s gaze to the heavens above,
The dim moon gradually grows bright.

□□  Tenth  Supreme  Auspicious

Auspicious repute overflows with boundless blessings,
The household brims with joy and felicity.
From whence comes the phoenix’s auspicious sign?
Virtue’s glory shines, bringing prosperity for generations.

Whether on level ground or mountain peaks,
All the boundless springtime beauty is claimed.
Having gathered the essence of a hundred flowers into honey,
For whom does one toil, and for whom is it sweet?

The imperial proclamation calls for worthy talents, courage and harmony aligned,
Just as spring’s hues are fitting to enter the gate.
Attaining office will ultimately lead to prominence,
Yet nothing compares to the stability of family wealth.

The Sage’s intent declares:
The Dao of the noble flourishes, the way of the petty wanes.
Seeking fame finds fulfillment, distinction in the imperial court.
A noble child is born, bringing future abundance.
Submitting memorials and strategies, one takes the lead in divination.
For the common person, such aspirations remain unattainable.
Vaguely adhering to the old ways,
One narrowly avoids calamity and misfortune.

Divining wealth—nobles prosper, while petty persons are present.
Small-scale acquisitions are auspicious.
Sell goods promptly; relocation is auspicious. Litigation is auspicious.
Farming depends on timing; mediocre transactions may succeed, but delay brings failure.
Household and family members are at peace; travel is auspicious.
Petty persons cling to the old; the traveler arrives in one or two days.
Illness afflicts both young and old with difficulty; the pox fares likewise.
Marriage—nobles and prominent persons find initial unions auspicious; remarriage is auspicious. Entering a household to seek heirs is auspicious.
Petty persons find small-scale trade auspicious.
Purchasing land, dwellings, servants, or livestock—nobles find it auspicious, petty persons struggle.
Documents bring auspiciousness to nobles, but misfortune to petty persons.
Plans and undertakings—nobles achieve prominence, while petty persons see no gain.
Nobles give birth to the noble; petty persons face separation.
Borrowing—nobles find it auspicious, petty persons gain nothing.
Lost items should be sought gradually. Relocation is auspicious.
Seeking medical treatment or education is auspicious. Entrusting others with matters is auspicious, but petty persons meet with failure.
Seeking official position, promotion, or appointment is auspicious.
In affairs, it is best to rest the mind and settle the body, which will gradually improve.

Like fading blossoms that remain as before,
Their colors now full and abundant.

□□  Eleventh  Supreme  Diligence in Action

Do not let footprints linger long in dust and obscurity;
Fortunately, a true scholar is a treasure at the feast.
Upholding integrity need not mean perpetual seclusion—
Await the moment when grinding and polishing open the ford.

The prisoner leaves jail, disputes are settled,
Then one buys sweet melons to ascend the tavern.
By chance, an old friend is met, and they drink together,
The wine bill is paid, and they toast one another again.

Why rush matters when setting out?
Even hurrying to Chang’an takes three days.
Better to stay home and heed the news,
For affairs must be witnessed firsthand to bring glory.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Talents and skills long buried in dust,
The time approaches when the path will open,
Bringing success and fulfillment to plans.
Most fitting to pursue aspirations,
Yet impossible to linger.

Marriage remains steady, lawsuits incur no loss.
Clinging to the old is unwise—lest one face humiliation.
Regarding wealth: for scholars in trade, full profit awaits;
Light goods are easy to acquire, and sales proceed smoothly.
Moving residence is inauspicious.
Lawsuits turn favorable, yet all matters meet obstruction.
Travelers arrive in two or three days—if not, trust the news.
Journeys prove auspicious.
The sick recover in three to five days without harm;
Prolonged illness may require a vow, but pox brings good fortune.
Marriage is favorable, and seeking wealth through marriage succeeds.
Lawsuits should be settled amicably.
Purchases—be it property, servants, livestock, or textiles—face delays but will conclude.
Childbirth yields a noble son, safe and sound.
All matters should be hastened, for delay invites trouble.
Relying on others brings good fortune; household and family remain at peace.
Documents bear an auspicious aura; transactions should be swift—delay risks failure.
Relocation and commerce prosper.
Seeking medicine or official promotion brings success.
Borrowing should be done quickly, for others may interfere.
What one desires will surely come to pass—
If only someone could know!
When the dragon soars, the ravine appears;
The timely rain falls just as it should.

[Missing characters] Twelfth: Lowest of the Low—Foul Conduct Obscures Clarity

Foul conduct deceives the heart, betraying Heaven’s gaze;
Ghosts and spirits ever watch one’s hidden ways.
If arrogance could summon fortune’s grace,
No good would walk the earth in human form.

Willow catkins swirl on the wind, lost without trace—
Like King Xiang’s dream, fleeting as a breath.
In the quiet of night, beneath the moon’s pale glow,
They drift and scatter, entangling the fragrant groves.

One may laugh at the traveler’s tale:
Yesterday he was poor—today, rich with coin.
Yet without diligence, nothing is gained;
Know this: only later comes fulfillment.

The Sage’s Intent declares:
Deceit within and without—ghosts and spirits offer no protection.
In all affairs and movements, one must fear misfortune and blame.
Whether plotting or acting, all endeavors prove difficult to achieve.
Atoning for transgressions and seeking forgiveness may yet avert calamity.
Before any action comes to fruition, it is best to maintain the status quo.
Though this slip is deemed greatly auspicious, all matters go awry.

For wealth: buying, selling, and stocking goods is favorable; selling brings profit.
For litigation: auspicious. For relocation: inauspicious.
On days marked by the fourth, twenty-sixth, forty-eighth, or thirty-fourth,
undertaking journeys invites disaster.
Travelers will arrive in two or three days; if not, they are detained by matters abroad.
For illness, whether young or old: afflicted by earth spirits or unfulfilled vows,
or one who has left the ancestral line and resides elsewhere—first seek aid from the household,
fulfill new vows swiftly, for delay endangers recovery.
For pox: ominous; preserving life brings good fortune.
For marriage: entering the groom’s home is greatly inauspicious.
For advancement or promotion: aspirations remain unfulfilled.
For purchasing land, homes, or livestock: inauspicious.
All schemes, plans, and undertakings prove unfavorable.
For childbirth: difficult. Household and family are unsettled—seek blessings for peace.
Relying on others for matters brings no success; people are hard to find.
Success turns to adversity; anxiety weighs heavily on the heart.
The trials of the Nai River are not yet passed—pray for blessings to avert misfortune.

□□ Thirteenth: Middling—Perseverance in the Old Ways

A steadfast nature, reverent and diligent, never slighting the gods;
In dealings with others, one remains fair and just.
How can one provoke resentment and reproach?
Better to withdraw the heart and preserve what is already achieved.

Flowers bloom and bear fruit, meeting their timely season,
Relying on the workings of spring’s transformative power.
All hopes and plans come to fruition,
And the dream of returning home in brocade robes may yet be realized.

Affairs endure, and so too does intent—
Yet amid them, a single moment stands strongest.
Act in accord with the times, without negligence,
And return home in brocade to pay homage to father and mother.

The Sage’s Intent declares:
One’s nature is reverent and faithful, never slighting the gods.
Conduct is upright and just, never deceiving others.
When others harbor resentment, it rebounds upon oneself.
How much better to seek stillness and preserve one’s true nature?
Do not pursue new schemes—maintain the old, and renewal will follow.

For wealth: ordinary transactions and stocking goods are inauspicious; expenditures bring no good.
For litigation: inauspicious. For farming: observe the seasons.
For travel: unfavorable. Travelers have not yet arrived.
For illness, regardless of age: prolonged suffering requires patience;
In urgent cases, recovery is difficult—pray for blessings and protection.

The pox likewise follows this pattern.
For marriage and entering a household: mediocre prospects for heirs.
Lost items will reappear with patience.
Purchasing fields, houses, servants, or livestock should be delayed in completion.
Seeking office or promotion brings honorable status; the household is at peace.
Plans and undertakings come to fruition—proceed with patience, not haste.
Childbirth requires calm; difficulties will pass.
Borrowed items will not be repaid.
Learning medicine or crafts demands patience.
Moving is unfavorable; documents will be delayed.
Busy yet unsettled in heart, tilling the fields with little strength.
Wait for the right time—then use it.
When clouds disperse, the moon is reborn.

[Missing character] Fourteenth: Most Inauspicious
Restlessness
Right and wrong blur in clamorous strife; lawsuits drag on without cease.
Wealth scatters, people part, and hardships multiply.
Preserve yourself, avoid harm, and reduce blame.
Dragons and snakes intermingle, difficult to restrain;
The scales of wind and cloud have yet to transform.
One day, riding clouds to return to the Northern Sea,
Only then will the dragon’s true form appear.

Hearing the road is perilous makes the journey seem hard—
Yet you say it is hard, but it is not.
Better to set out, cross the waters,
And return home to find all settled and safe.

The Sage’s Intent declares:
Entangled in right and wrong, contending in litigation.
People part, wealth scatters, losses are hard to recover.
Do not covet action—preserve your wholeness.
Travel is unfavorable; marriage has no affinity.
The sick have not recovered—pray to Heaven.
Abide by constancy and duty to avoid misfortune.

For business: stocking goods is inauspicious; selling is favorable.
Litigation brings no trouble; the sick will lose wealth—
Appease the earth and perform blessings for protection.
Farming yields no harvest.
Travelers will arrive soon; journeys are unfavorable—beware of disaster.
Lost items are hard to find and will not be seen.
Transactions are unfavorable.

Divining wealth: commerce wearies the mind, but purchasing goods is good.
Autumn and winter are auspicious; selling goods is swift.
Farming is incomplete; marriage is inauspicious.
Travel in autumn is favorable; travelers arrive.
Lawsuits are difficult; borrowing in autumn and winter is auspicious.
Illness afflicts young and old—
in spring and summer, recovery comes;
in autumn, healing is slow.
Much misfortune—good deeds are advised.
Illness in autumn and winter recovers late.
Buying fields, households, or livestock—
autumn and winter are auspicious; spring and summer, inauspicious.
Schemes and tasks—
autumn and winter are auspicious; spring and summer, not.
Households and family—
autumn and winter are auspicious.
Commerce, documents, childbirth—
all are auspicious in autumn and winter.
Seeking office or promotion—
autumn and winter are auspicious.
Relying on others for tasks is difficult;
shedding burdens is inauspicious in the first half of the year,
auspicious in the latter half.
Trade is auspicious in autumn and winter;
other months are unfavorable.

Grain ripens—now is the time to act,
with intent fixed on the cloud ladder.
All schemes and hopes are well-timed—
clouds part, the moon shines bright.

**[Missing character] Forty-Seventh: Great Auspice**
Innately holding pure sincerity, your conduct reaches the divine—
in due time, good fortune arrives.
If schemes stray from the straight path,
they will not err from the true Dao.

Dense clouds without rain darken the sky’s edge—
yet this portends doubt, not obstruction.
Beware of petty men harming you;
darkness veils the household—guard against affairs.

Seeking wealth, you desire unimpeded flow,
yet talent moves west, then east again.
Though three or five parts are substantial,
matters may yet end in one stroke of emptiness.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Good deeds bring fortune; evil accumulates misfortune.
Even when walking the right path,
blessings need not be sought.
Lawsuits settle peacefully; divining kin brings no worry.
All schemes succeed; journeys harbor doubt.
All affairs proceed as wished, without delay.

Divining wealth: upright commerce yields no profit;
devious paths flourish greatly.
Purchasing goods is good; selling goods is good.
Farming reaps great harvest; lawsuits are inauspicious.
Illness afflicts young and old—
obstacles from earth spirits require prayers for protection, but no harm.
Marriage is auspicious; all matters are fortunate.
Travel is auspicious; travelers arrive in three days.

Erecting a new grave unsettles—
sending letters strains the heart.
Several times you’ve faced perilous waves;
today, you meet a confidant.

**[Missing character] Forty-Eighth: Moderate – Yin and Yang**
Yin and yang pair not in vain—
strive to seek the divine, accumulating good affinity.
Moment by moment, who knows to follow great righteousness?
Better to safeguard wealth and ensure security.

A newly sharpened sword gleams brighter—
its east-west radiance surpasses the ordinary.
From the past, roots already exist;
polished and enhanced, its fame spreads.

Desiring lifelong wealth and harmony,
who knew good fortune would bring many demons?
Better to maintain the old—peaceful dwelling is auspicious.
Naturally, you possess soaring aspirations.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Seeking schemes brings great fortune, with destined affinity.
Yet if plotting, affairs may falter.
Preserve resources well; do not trifle with public matters.
Divining households requires caution.
The ill are unharmed; travelers are delayed.

Divining wealth: commerce yields little.
Purchasing goods is good; selling goods is good.
Seeking medical skills or official rank fails.
Lawsuits are inauspicious—losing wealth is no harm.
The ill recover through good vows.
Travel is unfavorable; travelers have not arrived.
Lost items will reappear; marriage is late but greatly auspicious.
Farming yields meager harvest.

Divining affairs: expect many obstacles.
Seeking rank or divination—outcomes are hard to measure.
To divine stability, maintaining the old brings peace—
naturally, glory and official position flourish.

Gathering four to form a woman—
beware, affairs may fail.
Early gardens secure provisions—
the household avoids disaster and misfortune.

**[Missing character] Forty-Ninth: Supreme – Breaking Star**
Who can distinguish jade within stone,
or pan for gold hidden in sand?
Prosperity and decline depend on timing—
why cling to empty aspirations?

A flock of crows gathers noisily—how strange!
Beware of slander from yin persons.
Only in retreat can you gain;
otherwise, affairs breed doubt.

Seeking matters in delay—delay is fitting.
Through long and enduring time, doubt not.

Wealth and goods long held are hard to keep—
holding them demands true vigilance.
The Sage’s intent declares:
One who trusts in talent yet fails to reach their aim—
with steadfast resolve, what cannot be achieved?

The sick shall recover on their own;
disputes will not long linger.
Plans advance, fortunes rise—
seizing opportunity brings honor.
All affairs flow smoothly,
heroic spirit unbroken.

Divining wealth: trade delayed yields four or five parts.
Farming rewards labor with harvest.
Lost items soon appear;
marriages should be swiftly sealed—auspicious.
Vows for the ill bring recovery—
the young fare well, the old less so.
Selling goods delayed brings profit;
haste yields none.
Public disputes best settled in peace;
travelers soon return, the household thrives.
All matters prosper.

The household’s renown grows,
documents stand firm.
Desires are fulfilled—
yet casting lines in the sea brings alarm.

The divination of the Four Sage Perfected Lords concludes.
*(Note: "魉魑" absent in the original text, supplied from context.)*

chunks.translated_text:
**Divine Lots of the Four Sage Perfected Lords**

*Scripture Title:* *Divine Lots of the Four Sage Perfected Lords*
*Author:* Unknown
*Volume:* One
*Source Text:* *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, Orthodox Section, Part One

**Divine Lots of the Four Sage Perfected Lords**
**Celestial Admonitions for the World**

To seek glory through deceit is to gain no renown.
Wealth amassed through exploitation brings calamity upon descendants.
Cultivate virtue with mindfulness, and fortune and blessings shall descend.
Curb desires, diminish self-interest, and your destiny shall endure.

Do not deceive in darkness, nor betray the Three Luminaries.
Be upright and selfless, with a loyal and sincere heart.
Heaven and Earth bestow blessings; the gods stand guard beside you.
Prolong life and transcend hardship—prosperity shall surely come.
If you heed my words, all afflictions shall vanish like the sea.

When praying, first state your native place and name, then declare:
*"For [such-and-such a matter], I humbly invoke the Perfected Lords—*
*Marshal Tianpeng the Great, Vice-Marshal Tianyu,*
*Lord Xusheng the Protector of Virtue, and Lord Zhenwu the Spiritually Responsive—*
*along with the gods of Heaven and Earth, who witness all things.*
*I now cast this lot: may good or ill be revealed,*
*fortune or misfortune be foretold, life or death be decided—*
*let the judgment be without doubt."*

---

**First Lot** □□ *Lower-Lower* **Uphold the Old**

From dawn to dusk, toil without rest,
Seeing only gold, not the man.
Though hoarded wealth may rot,
In time, even blossoms turn to dust.

The soaring dragon transforms when the hour is right—
Today, its ascent is fulfilled.
Plans and wealth-seeking bring great fortune;
Seeking office and promotion leave no doubt.

The fierce general storms the palace gates—
How dare petty schemes stir conflict?
You must pay homage at the golden gate,
Where lords above and below stand in harmony.

**Sacred Intent:**
Chasing profit at dawn, abandoning truth for delusion.
What is amassed cannot be dispersed—retribution follows slander.
Hold fast to the ordinary; do not scheme.
Do not stir litigation; marriages shall prosper.
The sick recover slowly; travel faces obstacles.
Actions fall short—no path lies ahead.
Auspicious in autumn, inauspicious in spring and winter.
Selling goods is favorable.
Litigation brings no trouble; buying and selling yields no profit,
Or if slight gains come, they cost great effort.
For those under fifty, illness lingers but does not last.
The young should recover early; lying abed longer is no harm.
Affected by earth, but smallpox is no threat.
Sudden illness—if young, sweat comes in seven days, and life is secure.
Marriage brings discord; if the husband enters the wife’s home, misfortune follows.
Seeking livestock or servants brings ill fortune.
Studying medicine or crafts is inauspicious; lost items are hard to recover.
Whether early or late, reunion is delayed and difficult.
Borrowed items are mostly not returned, or only a few.

Relocation brings misfortune; only guarding the old homestead is fitting.
Household members are afflicted by earth, with taboos unsettling peace.
Cultivate blessings to protect them—childbirth should be swift; delay makes official promotion difficult, though greatly auspicious.
Sell goods promptly when selling; documents remain unsigned, and delay prevents completion.
Those entrusted prove deceitful.
Buy goods promptly when buying; plans and actions come to fruition.
Obstacles arise; farming yields no harvest.
Meet noble persons at once—delay brings no success.
Acupuncture and moxibustion require choosing an auspicious day.
Cherishing flowers, yet rain falls; loving the moon, dark clouds arise.
At the feast, no matter seems settled, yet quarrels still contend.

[Missing characters] Second: Greatly Auspicious. Action and use bring advancement.
Seek shelter early to secure profit—
Diligently follow ancient methods, never overstepping time.
Reforming what is corrupt is people’s constant wish;
When deeds align with the heart, great rewards are enjoyed.
The tiger leaves the great forest, stirring the crowd—
Though people see it, they remain anxious and doubtful.
Though it harbors no intent to harm,
It still causes false alarms and suspicious affairs.
How can mountain dwellers host clamorous guests?
Better to cultivate the mind and refine oneself.
Amid all things, remain patient;
Burning with effort in alchemy is but vain labor.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Follow rules and norms, establish oneself by the Dao.
From long stillness comes the thought of movement—
Ever diligent and earnest.
Relocation is auspicious; plans proceed as the heart desires.
Marriage brings harmony; the ill recover lightly.
All matters flow smoothly; litigation brings joy.
Adhering to the Sage’s lot,
All desires prosper and flourish.

Divining marriage is auspicious.
Acquiring goods is of little value; selling goods is favorable.
Moving residence is auspicious.
Litigation brings no trouble; household and family are at peace.
Seeking office brings delayed promotion, yet rank is assured.
Illness should be treated swiftly.
Performing blessings is fitting—
For the elderly, recovery is difficult;
For the young, outcomes vary between good and ill.

chunks.original_text: 服药有阻，痘疮不稳。 出行远宜少人吉。 行人至，如不到两月方归。 失物在宅内，宜早寻，迟不见。 人口失吉。 久后见行人，不到一二日有信。 脱货、脱事便脱，后迟，孕难生，生女。 修福　　日下生。 求医入学吉。 托人用事二人方吉。 交易吉。 文书有阻，吉。 借物三人吉。 买头疋，田宅，快利。 有缘重欢庆，枯杨半树开。 向前求吉事，晚日称心怀。 □□　第三　中平　否极泰来 用尽殷勤望有功，反为怜怨惨愁容。 须愁宝货多虚耗，何苦区区不守中。 否极从今喜泰来，龙泉磨拂旧尘埃。 莫言守已无他望，闭户深居也获财。 居官必有人谗佞，得职终须后职高。 只好在家安守道，自然家内遇英豪。 圣意云：时运大谬，不能守常。 殷勤用尽，反受其殃。 失物招祸，动作不良。 凡事求用，早计潜藏。 大主损财，宜守其常。 占买物，田宅，人口、头疋难。 见货快买，再去添价，不卖有利，病老少。 若不应时，先凶后吉。 宅神不宁，婚姻克夫。 费力不成，种田费力。 无收守旧，脱货好。 公讼事难，谋事成事难。 旧基业好，新难去。 失人口头疋，难寻。 产孕生分娩难。 子母凶，宜作福生男。 托人用事不济，有阻。 文书不济，损财。 迁移不利。 借物无交易，兴贩不利。 守旧还逢吉，更张劳见危。 鼎身亏一足，烹饪但随时。 □□　第四　中平　谨守 莫言小疾沸须忧，日月适巡不易留。 能向道中图早计，庶几危厄获全收。 劳心费力欲成功，待得花开一阵风。 须得东君轻借力，望中别有一枝红。 风催闪电雷为使，水中绞龙旱有妖。 二物若能俱不避，依时顺节足为高。 圣意云：谨微守己，一心事神。 旧愿早还，免受其殃。 公讼不利，莫占婚姻。 出行宜止，在路迈巡。 财货平平，病者纵免。 凡合天道，先暗后明。 占病，有道愿先凶后吉。 久淹不妨，年老难。 痘疮宜保福，产难宜快，先凶后吉。 买卖微，见人宜快，有二三种田早收，迟无。 说货快，婚姻不吉。 入舍过房凶，出行心动，身不动，行人二三日至。 如不至，迟公讼吉。 破财买头疋快成，迟难。 求官升职，名分迟，不遂。 买物田宅宜快，迟不成。 走失，目下见； 如迟一日，不见。 成事勾当宜快，迟更变，家宅人口不利。 保福安，托人用事宜。 贵人迟，不成。 交易难成，兴贩宜快。 迁移凶，借物便借，有人组。 文书目下见，迟不成。 求医学业，迟难。 安居且虑危，深情有别离。 未能求善果。 先仿预损枝。 □□　第五　中平　利益动用 好将心意共图谋，利益源源合所求。 休向此中忘善果，保全衰朽浪中舟。 行船风顺去无疑，利涉江津正遇时。 万里长城知可到，所谋遂意事如期。 二人商贾求财利，便好登途离本地。 三五七朝到长安，货物交关莫守市。 圣意云：最宜交易，同心共谋。 若占老病，危厄孤舟，婚姻叶吉，谋望可求。 疾者进退，不解无忧，行人即至，讼不拘留。 田蚕吉利，家道优游。 占财，买卖置货好，合伴不吉。 公讼无事，婚姻吉。 种田有收，出行吉。 行人早晚至，求官升职，利病。 三五十以用无妨，四十以上进退宜快，保福。 痘疮平稳，老者主死。 买田宅、人口、头疋吉。 家宅老危少安，托人用事快吉。 迁移大吉。 走失迟见，谋事成事，三二日宜快干，迟不济。

Medication meets obstruction; pox sores remain unstable.
For distant travel, fewer companions bring good fortune.
The traveler arrives—if not, returns within two months.
Lost items lie within the home; seek them early, for delay brings no sight.
Household members meet good fortune.

After long absence, the traveler appears—within a day or two, news arrives.
Selling goods or matters should be done promptly; delay brings difficulty.
Pregnancy struggles to bear; a daughter is born.
Performing blessings—
The child is born now.
Seeking a physician or entering school is auspicious.
Entrusting matters to two people brings good fortune.
Trade is auspicious.
Documents meet obstruction, yet fortune prevails.
Borrowing from three people is auspicious.
Purchasing livestock, fields, or homes brings swift profit.
Joyful reunion with kindred spirits—withered willows bloom halfway.
Pursuing good fortune ahead, the heart’s desires are fulfilled in later days.

**Third: Moderate Fortune – From Adversity Comes Prosperity**
Exhausting diligence in hope of success,
Only to be met with sorrow and bitter countenance.
Worry not for the vain depletion of treasures—
Why toil in vain without holding to the mean?

From adversity now comes prosperity;
The dragon’s blade, polished, sheds its old dust.
Say not that self-restraint holds no other hope—
Even in seclusion, wealth is gained.

In office, slanderers arise,
Yet promotion follows in time.
Best to stay home, uphold the Dao,
And naturally, heroes appear within the household.

The Sage’s intent declares:
The times run contrary, unable to hold to constancy.
Diligence exhausted, one suffers calamity instead.
Lost items invite misfortune; actions turn ill.
In all matters, plan early and act in secret.
Great losses of wealth—best to maintain the norm.

Divining purchases—fields, homes, livestock, or servants prove difficult.
See goods and buy swiftly; to haggle further brings no profit.
Illness affects young and old.
If untimely, first ill, then good.

Household spirits are restless; marriage harms the husband.
Efforts fail; farming is laborious.
No harvest—hold to the old; selling goods is favorable.
Litigation is troublesome; plans and actions falter.
Old foundations are sound; new ventures are difficult.
Lost livestock or servants are hard to recover.
Childbirth is difficult; mother and child face peril.
Performing blessings may yield a son.
Entrusting matters to others brings no success—only obstruction.
Documents bring no benefit; wealth is lost.
Relocation is inauspicious.
Borrowing brings no trade; commerce is unfavorable.
Holding to the old brings good fortune; change invites danger.
The tripod lacks a leg—cooking must adapt to the times.

**Fourth: Moderate Fortune – Cautious Restraint**
Say not that minor illness is but a fleeting worry—
Time and tide wait for none.
If one plans early within the Dao,
Perhaps peril may yet yield safety.

Laboring heart and strength to succeed,
Only to see the blossoms scattered by a gust of wind.
Yet if the Eastern Lord lends a gentle hand,
Another branch blooms in the distance.

Wind spurs lightning, thunder serves as messenger;
Drought breeds demons in the waters where dragons twist.
If one can avoid neither,
Timing and harmony suffice for excellence.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Be cautious in small matters, hold to oneself, and serve the spirits wholeheartedly.
Fulfill old vows early to avoid calamity.
Litigation is unfavorable; do not divine marriage.
Travel should be halted; the road is fraught with delay.
Wealth is modest; illness may yet be spared.
All aligns with the Dao—first dark, then bright.

Divining illness—vows bring first ill, then good.
Prolonged affliction is no concern, but the elderly face difficulty.
Pox sores require blessings; childbirth demands swift action—first ill, then good.
Trade is modest; meet people promptly—two or three crops should be harvested early, or none at all.
Speak of goods quickly; marriage is inauspicious.
Adopting or moving into a home is ill-fated.
Travel stirs the heart, but the body remains—
The traveler arrives in two or three days.
If not, delay brings good fortune in litigation.
Spending to buy livestock brings swift success; delay brings difficulty.
Seeking office or promotion—rank comes late, and desires are unmet.
Purchasing goods, fields, or homes should be done quickly; delay brings failure.
Lost items appear at once; if delayed by a day, they vanish.
Matters should be settled swiftly; delay brings change.
Household and family face misfortune.
Performing blessings brings peace.
Entrusting matters to others is favorable.
Noble aid comes late and fails.
Trade is difficult; commerce should be swift.
Relocation is ill-fated.
Borrowing should be done promptly, though others may interfere.
Documents appear at once; delay brings failure.
Seeking physicians or studies is difficult with delay.
Dwelling in peace yet fearing danger,
Deep emotions bring separation.
Before good fruit can be sought,
First, one must suffer the loss of a branch.

**Fifth: Moderate Fortune – Beneficial Action**
With good intent, plan and scheme together—
Profit flows endlessly to meet your desires.
Do not forget good deeds in this pursuit,
Lest the withered vessel drift in the waves.

The sailing ship meets favorable winds without doubt;
Crossing the river is timely.
The Great Wall of ten thousand li is within reach—
Plans succeed as hoped, matters proceed as scheduled.

Two merchants seeking profit—
Best to set out and leave their homeland.
In three, five, or seven days, they reach Chang’an,
Where goods are traded—do not linger in the market.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Trade is most favorable; unite in purpose and plan.
For the elderly and ill, peril is like a lone boat.
Marriage is harmonious; plans and hopes may be pursued.
Illness wavers, yet without resolution, there is no worry.
The traveler arrives soon; litigation brings no detention.
Silkworms and fields bring good fortune; the household thrives in ease.

Divining wealth—buying, selling, and acquiring goods is favorable, though partnerships are inauspicious.
Litigation brings no trouble; marriage is auspicious.
Farming yields harvest; travel is fortunate.

◇◇ 19 ◇◇ Most Auspicious ◇◇ Fine Wood Meets Spring

A hundred blessings stir as earth meets spring’s return,
Warm breaths revive, all things assume their freshest mien.
Should fortune align with this season’s radiant scene,
Behold the long-delayed dawn of fragrant days unfold.

Clouds drift and rain descends in spring’s deep embrace;
All schemes and wealth-seeking find their heart’s desire.
Disputes with officials yield just outcomes fair,
While noble ones seek joy and blessings in their wake.

Heed not the clamor of others’ praise or blame—
Though gains may come, they lack true strength or height.

The days ahead shall shine with boundless, bright success.

Cast off the old and welcome the new; life flourishes in vibrant growth.

Travelers journey smoothly; lawsuits incur no penalty.

Endless snow envelops all,
Yet tender willows meet spring’s call.
All schemes unfold in such a way—

◇◇ 20 ◇◇ Most Inauspicious ◇◇ Peril and Void

In haste, one seeks the gods with forced sincerity,
Yet such devotion fails to move the divine.
Facing peril, one fears no safety can be found;
All hopes dissolve—success remains beyond reach.

A boat without oars drifts helplessly,
Swept by currents toward the boundless sea.
Alas, how many souls are led astray,
Wandering east and west in vain pursuit.

Those who act find their affairs unfulfilled;
Once achieved, they swiftly turn away.
If you seek this fate, all proves inauspicious—
Only through divination may peace be secured.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Human hearts grow lax, defiling the sacred with impurity.
Peril and danger loom; illness lingers in hesitation.
Plans falter; marriages fail to form.
Only through reverent offerings may protection be secured.
Lawsuits end in defeat; trade brings sorrow.
To seek fortune in travel, swiftly appeal to the heavens above.

For wealth: purchasing few goods is auspicious; sell promptly when possible.
Lawsuits face obstruction; marriages prove favorable.
Most matters conclude, but avoid planting crops.
Illness stems from disrespect to household deities—obstacles weigh heavily.
Offer prayers for blessings; prolonged suffering may ease, turning from grave to mild.
Beware of further affliction. Travel is inauspicious; travelers have not yet arrived.
Purchasing fields, houses, or servants may succeed, but gains will not endure—all proves unfavorable.
Lost items are hard to recover; relying on others brings no result.

◇◇ 21 ◇◇ Most Inauspicious ◇◇ Stagnation and Delay

Fine jade and bright pearls are not easily won—
Their blessings align with past merits long sown.
To grasp the truth of fate’s rise and fall,
One frets in vain, graying before their time.

A fish transforms into a roc, riding ocean waves,
As yin and yang harmonize in times of peace.
Even common folk may harbor lofty dreams—
A thunderous roar from flat ground stirs all anew.

The present scene is fraught with hardship’s weight;
Each day, one seeks to shed the old for change.
Trade and wealth slip ever out of reach—
Yet in your heart, let no despair take root.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Accumulated virtue brings blessings to the household.
Accumulated vice invites calamity to the door.
All follows nature’s course—why sink into despair?
Heirs are hard to secure; all undertakings falter.
Begin nothing new; guard your heart and wait.

For wealth: trading old goods is favorable; selling proves inauspicious.
Farming yields blossoms but no fruit.
Travel is inauspicious; travelers arrive ill.
For illness, young or old, the next day or two may bring relief—delay brings difficulty. The same holds for pox.
Marriages are auspicious; seeking heirs is inauspicious.
Trade is hard to conclude; lawsuits prove favorable.
Purchasing fields, houses, servants, or livestock is inauspicious. Lost items are hard to recover.
Plans and accomplishments prove inauspicious.
Childbirth is difficult; borrowed items are unavailable.
Learning crafts is inauspicious; seeking office or rank meets no success.
Relocation is inauspicious; relying on others for matters brings no result.
Documents remain unresolved.

A moon veiled by dark clouds drifts,
No distant paths lie ahead.
Wealth brings loss; misfortune lingers—
Illness yet finds no cure.

◇◇ 22 ◇◇ Greatly Auspicious ◇◇ Later Fortune

One refines their craft with diligence, mastering knowledge deep,
Their nature as clear as still waters, profound and bright.
Long cherished treasures hold boundless worth—
Only when sold does their true value shine.

A phoenix takes flight from the forest,
Spreading its wings to soar above all birds.
One day, it ascends to the imperial court,
Admired and renowned in every land.

Spur the horse on the long road ahead,
Reaching the capital in a day or two.
In the imperial city, a carefree guest—
Early arrival secures office, fate’s design.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Through steadfast study, one’s talents remain unrecognized—
Long mired in hardship, plans fail to unfold.
Yet when the time comes, old paths lead to renewal,
Like withered wood blooming anew.
No need for distant worries—all matters shall succeed.
Lawsuits bring peace; all actions align with desire.
Plans come to fruition; all endeavors prosper.

For wealth: trade and sales yield modest gains in the present.
Purchasing goods brings light profit; selling may be slow.

□□ Twenty-Third: *Moderate Balance* – *The Image of Temporal Obstruction*
Things remain, yet people change—let go of attachments,
Lest grievances and lawsuits turn to mutual provocation.
Though the heart shines bright as a mirror,
How can one endure when fortune’s hour has not yet come?

Peach trees planted fill the eastern courtyard,
Their blossoms battered by rain and wind.
Once hoped for fruit to savor,
Now all that remains is emptiness.

How wondrous the immortal’s art—
If you pursue it, you’ll transcend the world.
When the Dao’s fruit ripens and the elixir is refined,
The golden gate opens at the appointed time.

The Sage’s intent declares:
The hour is obstructed, the fate adverse—
Many troubles, many disputes,
All exhaust the heart and mind,
Yet who pities your woes?
Hold fast to the old and await the turning of the times.
First misfortune, then fortune;
Plans and hopes are delayed.
Seeking marriage brings distant success;
Litigants face no danger.
In all matters, proceed with patience—
Why harbor doubts?

For wealth: the later the trade, the greater the profit. Purchasing goods is favorable; selling may be slow but ultimately good. In all affairs, remain still and steady. Purchasing fields, estates, or servants is auspicious if delayed; household and family remain at peace. Lost items are hard to recover; plans and accomplishments face initial difficulty but later ease. Relocation is favorable; seeking office or rank brings eventual great fortune. Documents and correspondence face delay but later succeed; borrowing is possible, though entrusting others fares better later.

Longing for the bright moon,
It waxes full, then wanes again.
Intentions may bloom like spring,
Yet in the end, all warmth fades.

□□ Twenty-Fourth: *Supreme* – *Receiving Blessings and Fortune*
A person of wealth and power, favored by auspicious spirits,
All actions proceed as the heart desires, naturally trusted.
Boldly venture into the tiger’s den,
And in time, you shall inherit the dragon’s pearl.

The bright moon hangs in the sky, illuminating all,
Its radiance dispelling every darkness.
All plans flourish; the household thrives—
This is the time for glory and prosperity.

If you speak of this matter, it must be praised,
Yet entrusting it to others leads astray.
Hasten to cultivate the heart and retreat to the mountains,
To escape the world’s entanglements, tangled as hemp.

The Sage’s intent declares:
By nature bold and proud,
You favor lofty heights.
Divine spirits aid your cause;
Profit and integrity are upheld.
Your conduct commands respect;
Lawsuits bring no toil.
A noble son is born,
And all things flow abundantly.
The sick recover swiftly;
Hopes are soon fulfilled.
Plans come to fruition;
Promotions and advancements rise.

Lost items are hard to recover; transactions succeed well. Trade ventures prosper; seeking office or promotion brings great fortune. Entrusting others with tasks faces initial difficulty but later ease.

□□ Twenty-Fifth: *Most Inauspicious* – *No Disaster Unmet*
Fortune meets misfortune; blessings are scarce—
Flee and hide, do not act lightly.
Merchants and traders should adhere to the old ways;
Watch for schemes that show only promise.

Hopes for success fall short of your desires;
The path to high office grows ever distant.
Remaining patient and steadfast is the true fortune—
In time, glory will surely appear.

One day, your affairs may seem praiseworthy,
But in the long run, they lead to wealth and splendor.
Some fail, some succeed—how many things are so?
Though the melon may be large, it remains sweet or bitter.

The Sage’s intent declares:
The hour is adverse, fate obstructed—
Best to retreat and hide.
Forced efforts bring no lasting labor.
Journeys risk bandits; the elderly toil in vain.
Farming yields no harvest; marriages bring endless chatter.
Hold fast to the old; do not cling to ambitions.

Transactions are difficult and unstable. Purchasing fields, estates, servants, or livestock is only favorable if they are your original property—otherwise, no benefit. **Hexagram Twenty-Seven: Utmost Adversity (向善)**
With nets spread and snares set, intent fixed,
one drives and schemes across the Central Plains.
Knowing only self-interest, demanding bribes,
who could foresee that words would bring disaster to the door?
Households are restless, the master uneasy—
all due to ancestral misfortunes bringing calamity.
Best to perform blessings and seek exorcism,
and thank the household gods for their service.
Though affairs seem peaceful, wealth comes slowly;
crossing rivers and mountains yields meager profit.
Only after long effort will true gain appear—
even then, excess is unnecessary.

**The Sage’s Intent:**
Human hearts are perilous; things rest uneasy in their cages.
Knowing only harm, how can one preserve the old?
All affairs are inauspicious; do not evade misfortune.
For now, seek respite; honor good deeds.
The sick grow worse; lawsuits yield no success.
In all matters, patience brings resolution.

**Divining Wealth:**
Buying and selling should be swift; acquiring goods is favorable, and selling is smooth. Farming yields nothing; neither high nor low ground is profitable. Lawsuits are auspicious; journeys are favorable. The traveler arrives within one or two days; if not, the elderly and young may fall ill. Childbirth yields a son; a daughter brings false alarms. Commerce is favorable; buying fields, houses, or livestock incurs loss without benefit. Plans and undertakings should proceed without hesitation; seeking office or promotion should be swift. Relocation is auspicious; documents arrive promptly. Relying on others brings quick success; lost items remain unseen. Households and family members are at peace.

Wheels turn with heavy loads;
meeting oxen risks financial loss.
Worries have not yet passed,
when mourning garments arrive again.

**Hexagram Twenty-Eight: Moderate Stability (谨守)**
Disasters and sorrows stir, yet no harm befalls—
strengthen your defenses and act with goodness.
Do not seek long-term plans from relatives;
schemes and cunning are but ordinary.
Noble patrons offer new assistance;
official troubles and gossip leave the household.
The sick recover health;
hopes and quests for wealth transform entirely.
Entrusting others with your affairs,
turn back early to gaze upon your homeland.
Best to safeguard yourself—
greed will surely invite disaster.

**The Sage’s Intent:**
Minor misfortunes gradually clear, not yet harming others.
Be vigilant early; do not procrastinate.
Lawsuits are lost; the sick sink deeper.
Marriages are half-successful; aspirations turn to dust.
Only by honoring blessings does one gain renewal.

**Divining Wealth:**
Buying and selling should conclude early and fairly; farming yields no harvest. Journeys are inauspicious; the traveler has not arrived. Relocation is unfavorable; the sick should take medicine. Beneath the bridge, water flows away;
from the stove, smoke curls long.
Preserve well-being by performing blessings—

Hidden traces shift and transform;
grace and favor descend from ancestral masters.
One day, fortune is grasped and power held—

When yin and yang align, affairs prosper;

Lute and zither harmonize, the household thrives—
glory, wealth, and nobility arise daily.

Ten years of study beneath the window,
the imperial examination summons the worthy.
Swift as the wind, two days’ journey—

**The Sage’s Intent:**
Long misfortune turns to fortune; long stagnation gradually opens.
Receiving favor from above, power is firmly held.
Litigation succeeds; plans and ventures strike true.
Marriages bring benefit; joy abounds.
The sick recover slowly; transactions proceed smoothly.

The stars encroach upon the moon—beware of trouble ahead,
Minor ailments bring misfortune, heralding calamity.
Yet if one knows and calls out halfway,
Preemptive offerings to heaven may avert disaster.

Settling down yet planning to leave the neighborhood,
Trade and ventures lie far away.
Relying on Buddha and gods brings fortune—
Seek the temple halls and shrines for success.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Long a wanderer at the edge of the sky,
Kinfolk sigh in sorrow.
Though thoughts pour out in vain,
One finds peace and joy alone.
Plans align with fortune,
Livestock thrives.
Marriages harmonize,
Lawsuits bring praise.
First inauspicious, then auspicious—
All affairs proceed without error.
The ill need not worry,
Fortune and longevity extend far.

On wealth: trade yields two or three parts profit,
Goods bought are fine, goods sold are fine.
Farming brings harvest,
Lawsuits are auspicious,
Illness spares none—old and young grow grave.
The young should do good deeds—
Marriage remains unobstructed,
Entering a household to seek heirs may not succeed.
The household suffers minor losses,
Unrest calls for virtuous protection.
Buying fields or homes brings minor losses first, then success.
Plans and actions face small setbacks at first,
No harm in borrowing,
Seeking medicine or craft brings good fortune.
Pregnancy proceeds smoothly and auspiciously,
Lost documents or items will be found,
Moving brings good fortune.
Seeking office or promotion meets success—trade flourishes.

A lone leaf skims the misty waves,
The boat sails with the current.
Wealth comes from afar,
All undertakings prosper in due course.

---

Hexagram Thirty-Three: Great Auspice—Bearing Blessings Beyond the Dust

Lush clouds and mist renew the scene,
The courtyard thrives, joyful as spring.
Contentment brings the blessing of heirs,
Merchants chance upon rare treasures.

The newly sharpened dragon sword gleams sharp,
Its mighty qi surges, unmatched by the ox.
Now held in hand,
Even heroes appear ordinary.

Consulting at dawn brings fortune,
Seeking after meals yields no favor.
All matters follow this truth—
Fame spreads across the four seas, winning praise.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Virtue flourishes, blessings abound,
Auspicious and kind.
Plans may not prosper,
Schemes may not favor.
Marriages harmonize,
Merchants thrive in numbers.
Pregnancy bears a noble son—
Do not move.
Disasters do not arise,
Inner and outer realms are harmonious.
All affairs proceed as wished,
Joy and fortune abound.

On wealth: a small investment brings great satisfaction,
Goods bought are fine, goods sold are fine.
Farming should be delayed,
Lawsuits are auspicious.
Moving brings great fortune.
Illness afflicts old and young—
Light in spring, grave in autumn and winter.
Good deeds help,
The stars are unfavorable.
Marriage should proceed swiftly—delay brings failure.
The household and its members are safe,
Lost items in the capital will be found among kin.

Trade delayed brings profit,
Buying fields or homes succeeds later.
Documents take time to finalize,
Pregnancy bears a son—smooth and greatly auspicious.
Plans and actions should proceed swiftly—
Delay brings no benefit.
Patience serves well in matters,
Seeking medicine or craft—haste fails, delay succeeds.
Relying on others brings fortune later,
Selling goods later yields greater profit.

Mist thickens like layered cloth,
Wine overflows the brimming cup.
Long-held commands soon depart,
Ripe fruit heralds blossoming flowers.

---

Hexagram Thirty-Four: Supreme Auspice—Joyful Renewal

Building a home or burying the dead meets auspicious spirits—
Proceed with construction without hesitation.
Merchants and traders see their plans succeed,
No need to scheme—good news arrives.

The ailing dragon brings rain beneath the rainbow,
Illness bodes ill for one’s affairs.
Transformation and ascent will come in time—
For now, maintain the old and await brighter days.

Know that some matters are best done in a day,
Let not a single day pass in vain.
If a task is ill-timed and inauspicious,
The noble one’s efforts are wasted.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Renewing the old, forging the new,
Moving graves and tombs.
Auspicious months and years align,
Favorable stars descend.
Merchants find joy in profit,
Marriages fulfill desires,
Plans succeed without effort,
Lawsuits bring hope,
All undertakings satisfy the heart.
Everlasting prosperity is assured.

On wealth: light trade should proceed swiftly,
Goods bought are fine, goods sold take time.
Farming should be hastened for early harvest.
Trade flourishes,
Travel should be swift,
Travelers arrive in a day or two—no delay.
The household and its members face misfortune.
Trade should proceed swiftly—delay brings failure,
Marriage should proceed swiftly—delay brings hardship.
Lawsuits bring no trouble,
Buying fields or homes succeeds later.
Plans and actions should proceed swiftly—
Delay brings difficulty.
Seeking medicine or craft brings stability,
Documents should be handled swiftly and auspiciously.
Seeking office or promotion succeeds,
Moving brings good fortune.
Lost items are hard to find,
Relying on others meets noble assistance.

Do not move.
Gradually, one reaches the shore,
All matters align with the heart.
What brings joy to one’s heart,
Falls like flowers, then blooms anew.

---

Hexagram Thirty-Five: Moderate—Seek Not, Move Not

The local spirits and malevolent forces forbid construction,
Preserve the old—do not seek elsewhere.
Disturbing tombs and earth is especially fearful—
Hastening to honor the gods brings great blessing.

The crane cries in the heavens, its qi piercing the sky,
Nine thousand li shrink to a hand’s breadth.
Official rank and wealth ascend daily,
Peaceful living brings joy through the seasons.

Each departure leaves more behind,
Yet seeking again brings even greater harmony.
If this hexagram appears between the twentieth and thirtieth,
Know that wealth will fill the mountains and rivers.

The Sage’s intent declares:
Undertaking construction or digging soil,
Evil forces occupy the direction.
Unintended actions are unwise—
Preserving the old is best.
Burials are especially forbidden,
Lest they bring ruin.
If minor transgressions occur,
Prayers and offerings restore peace.
Public and private affairs suffer,
Beware of disaster.
Hastening to do good
Brings fortune.

On wealth: trade and buying goods are fine,
Sell goods promptly.
Public matters are auspicious—
Maintain the old for the 31st, 4th, or 10th.
Undertakings and travel are inauspicious,
Travelers do not arrive, delayed by obstacles abroad.
Entering a household to seek heirs brings misfortune.

Once defenses fail, chaos reigns unchecked.
Wealth scatters—seeking blessings anew,

Fish leap through peach-blossom waves in the third month,

Seeking office and emolument finds certainty,

By chance, in drought years, low fields are sown,

Hearing rumors of locusts and calamity,

Failing to uphold the law, ever prone to negligence—

Plans and accomplishments turn ill.
Childbirth harms mother and child—guard well-being.
Fields and dwellings near rivers are unfavorable; documents bring no advantage.

Vexation and haste fill the heart, toiling dreams dissolve like mist.

**Hexagram Thirty-Seven: Utterly Inauspicious – Abide in Stillness**
Fortune has roots as misfortune has a womb—
All summoned by man’s own hand.
A heart set on ill invites calamity;
Even with luck, the body may survive, yet wealth is lost.
How to cross waters without a boat?
Waves and billows rise in towering fury.
Neither advance nor retreat yields escape—
Follow not this path in all your comings and goings.
A lifetime spent wandering as a traveler,
What trade or profit ever thrives?
If buying food with a knife, act swiftly—
Know that haste brings advantage, east or west.

The Sage declares:
A life steeped in harm—
Fortune scant, misfortune manifold.
Now beset by sudden woe,
What recourse remains?
Plans fall short; kin stand divided.
Litigation loses merit; commerce grinds to ruin.
Best to keep to the old—
Why chase restless waves?

Buying and selling fare poorly;
Acquiring goods brings hindrance, but selling brings fortune.
Farming is unfavorable.
Illness is inauspicious—cold damage, sores, and boils—

Relocation is inauspicious; borrowed items are lost.
Commerce leads to loss; litigation fails.
Documents bring no advantage; buying fields, dwellings, or servants invites loss and misfortune.
Seeking office or promotion goes unfulfilled.

Where do thorns arise?
The beloved’s trust slowly fades.
The lute’s broken strings fall silent—

Illness lingers, pitiably frail—

Sincere pleas and vows prove vain—

The red sun pierces the clouds,
Illuminating all, even the hidden—
The multitudes turn their gaze.
The nobleman advances, his path bright,

When buying, prices soar—
Sell at a bargain, do not hesitate.
Though profit is meager,
Wandering here is but wasted effort.

Disaster clings like a web—
Who could foresee its source?
Unfulfilled vows endanger safety;
Physicians and shamans spin tales, squandering coin.
Hasten to cultivate virtue
To appease Heaven above.
First sorrow, then joy;
First hardship, then ease.
Perform good deeds—
The gods will grant protection.

**Divination on Wealth:**
Do not purchase goods; selling them is favorable. Farming yields little. Illness in old age is inauspicious—heavenly vows and curses linger, celestial signs are adverse, and illness worsens. Travel brings misfortune, though a traveler may arrive. Childbirth is difficult; lawsuits are inauspicious and protracted. Marriage is unfavorable; relocation is ill-advised. Buying land, homes, or servants is unpropitious—perform good deeds for the household. Seeking medical or artistic skills is unprofitable; lost items are hard to recover. Pursuing office or promotion is unfavorable—hasten to resolve matters, for success is unlikely. Borrowing brings initial difficulty, then ease; entrusting others follows the same pattern.

Eight blades remain unfinished,
Dark arrows strike the unseen.
Harm to others returns to oneself—
Fortune departs, misfortune invades.

**[Missing character] Thirty-Ninth: Neutral – Guard Against Humiliation**
Speak not of heroes untouched by misfortune—
Grand ambitions meet disgrace, hard to endure.
Turn back, amend faults—no shame in correction;
Seek the open path, inquire wisely.

Suddenly lost in deep mountains,
Better to return, free of doubt.
Advance or retreat, travel—all bring misfortune;
Beware hidden deceit and loss.

Though goods arrive late, their prospects are bright—
Best to maintain the old and observe the bold.
When a leader emerges, fortune turns auspicious,
And wealth later flows like a blade.

**The Sage’s Intent:**
The strong and lawless
Lightly bully the good and kind.
Vicious debts are hard to seize—
Suffering disgrace, one is cast aside.
Yet amend faults once,
And misfortune vanishes, no more to return.
First ill, then good—
All depends on timely action.
This lot is not auspicious;
Hasten to fulfill old vows.

**Divination on Wealth:**
Buying, selling, and trading goods are favorable; selling is auspicious. Farming yields nothing. Travel is unfavorable; travelers face obstacles. Entrusting others brings no success; the ill should seek protection. Marriage is inauspicious; childbirth requires safeguarding. Plans and actions should be altered—even success is unfavorable. Lawsuits should be settled amicably; buying old homes or servants is unpropitious. Documents are unfavorable; relocation is ill-advised. Seeking medical or artistic skills is unprofitable. Pursuing office or promotion succeeds if one entrusts others again. Borrowing is unfavorable; lost items, if sought quickly, may not be found.

Fading blossoms gradually revive,
The broken moon regains its round.
Amend faults, and gods and men will praise—
Reunion ensures completion.

**[Missing character] Fortieth: Neutral – Later Auspicious**
A heart harboring malice, lacking kindness,
In life and death, filial impiety spreads.
Yet turn toward the Dao, reform the old—
A foundation endures, heirs thrive in the household.

The swan soars to the heavens, naturally,
But before its time arrives, misfortune strikes.
This day, ascension brings freedom—
Soaring straight to the clouds of the nine skies.

Hearing news, the truth is praiseworthy;
Approach the gate, and splendor awaits.
If you entrust others, it ends inauspiciously—
Empty words tangle worldly affairs like hemp.

**The Sage’s Intent:**
A lifetime of malice,
Disharmony with kin.
Transforming life and death,
Turn toward this heart.
Swear to heaven, repent to earth,
Reform the old, renew the new.

Illness gradually lessens; plans and ventures succeed.
For marriage or lawsuits, peace is ultimately achieved.
Shift from ill to good—
Joy fills the household.

**Divination on Wealth:**
Delay brings profit; purchasing goods is good, selling is good. Farming faces initial difficulty, then ease. Marriage is inauspicious. Lost items, if sought urgently, remain at home. Documents are delayed; trade is favorable. Borrowing brings delayed profit; entrusting others is urgent and auspicious. Transactions succeed with delay and profit; childbirth is auspicious after delay.

Meeting or not—first guard against obstruction and disaster.
Return to the true Dao,
And avoid losing segmental wealth.

**[Missing character] Forty-First: Neutral – Caution, Do Not Act**
The traveler’s road stretches endlessly, ancient inns lie desolate—
Opening one’s eyes only invites separation.
Best to maintain the old, passing days in peace,
To preserve contentment and steady fortune.

Falling blossoms, flowing water—both heartless,
The household is troubled, the master uneasy.
Women and children face illness and hardship—
Hasten to pray to the gods of prosperity.

Though treasures emerge from the sea,
Boarding a foreign ship is a vain journey.
Arriving, one knows not where to go—
Returning empty-handed, bare as before.

**[Missing character] Forty-Second: Great Auspice – Awakening**
Long dullness stirs, as if waking from drunkenness,
Suddenly thoughts of change arise, though not yet to their source.
Ice melts, snow scatters, and the gentle breeze arrives—
The sunken rise in secret, the withered flourish anew.
Fish leap from the water, playing amidst the waves,
Leaping and gliding—do not take this lightly.
Fortune comes with ease, all matters flow smoothly,
Even in peril, victory surpasses the past.
Do not boast of martial prowess or extraordinary feats,

Illness in the old or young recovers quickly in spring, but slowly in other months. Entrusting others with tasks—act swiftly; resolving matters—act swiftly. Household and family are at peace; seeking office or promotion is auspicious. From drunken stupor to awakening, long hardship gradually gives way to smoothness. When the worst is past, fortune arrives—new shoots emerge from the earth.

**[Missing character] Forty-Third: Neutral – Aligning with Heaven**
Life’s toil rarely sees seventy,
Yin and yang’s excesses—seek a physician swiftly.
Heaven’s decree on lifespan is predetermined,
Not for mortal dust to know lightly.
The sun rises over Fusang, illuminating ten thousand miles—
Nobles rejoice, and all flows smoothly.
Seeking wealth and schemes follows the heart’s desire;
Asking for office—surely one will gain a name.
Since ancient times, the talented and ambitious stand tall,
Yet in their midst, affairs do not align.
Not a single flaw in their schemes—
In an instant, fame shines upon the great assembly.
